citations.desc: Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC).
citations.narrative:
Research monitoring procedures involving the use of dogs is not being followed according to the IACUC approved
protocol. The protocol states that from day 10 until the end of the study the dogs will be monitored daily for appetite,
activity level, stool quality, hydration status, and mucous membrane color and the results will be documented in the
records. However, upon review of all records, there is no evidence that this monitoring was being conducted as written in
the protocol. Failure to adhere strictly to the activities described in a research protocol prevents full Institutional Animal
Care and Use Committee (IACUC) oversight of activities and may adversely affect animal welfare. Correct by ensuring
the IACUC has the opportunity to review and approve, require modifications in (to secure approval), or withhold approval
of proposed significant changes regarding the care and use of animals in ongoing activities. Correct by August 27, 2024.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
The primary enclosures housing four dogs are only being sanitized once a month, according to the facility, due to
research purposes. However, there is no exception documented and approved by the IACUC in the research protocol.
Not sanitizing primary enclosures every 2 weeks presents an increased risk of disease and may adversely affect the
health of dogs. Correct by ensuring all primary enclosures for dogs are sanitized at least once every 2 weeks or more
often as necessary to prevent disease hazards. To be corrected by August 13, 2024.

The facility does not have a complete and signed program of veterinary care for dogs. The current program of veterinary
care does not include all the required components of 3.13(a). An incomplete program of veterinary care for dogs may lead
to inadequate veterinary care or preventative care. Correct by ensuring that the facility has a complete program of
veterinary care for dogs that is developed, documented in writing, and signed by the attending veterinarian. Correct by
August 20, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
Michael Brooks, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER
Ronald Richardson, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.31(c)(7) 
   
Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC). 
Research monitoring procedures involving the use of dogs is not being followed according to the IACUC approved 
protocol. The protocol states that from day 10 until the end of the study the dogs will be monitored daily for appetite, 
activity level, stool quality, hydration status, and mucous membrane color and the results will be documented in the 
records. However, upon review of all records, there is no evidence that this monitoring was being conducted as written in 
the protocol. Failure to adhere strictly to the activities described in a research protocol prevents full Institutional Animal 
Care and Use Committee (IACUC) oversight of activities and may adversely affect animal welfare. Correct by ensuring 
the IACUC has the opportunity to review and approve, require modifications in (to secure approval), or withhold approval 
of proposed significant changes regarding the care and use of animals in ongoing activities. Correct by August 27, 2024. 
3.11(b)(2) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
The primary enclosures housing four dogs are only being sanitized once a month, according to the facility, due to 
research purposes. However, there is no exception documented and approved by the IACUC in the research protocol. 
Not sanitizing primary enclosures every 2 weeks presents an increased risk of disease and may adversely affect the 
health of dogs. Correct by ensuring all primary enclosures for dogs are sanitized at least once every 2 weeks or more 
often as necessary to prevent disease hazards. To be corrected by August 13, 2024. 
3.13(a) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The facility does not have a complete and signed program of veterinary care for dogs. The current program of veterinary 
care does not include all the required components of 3.13(a). An incomplete program of veterinary care for dogs may lead 
to inadequate veterinary care or preventative care. Correct by ensuring that the facility has a complete program of 
veterinary care for dogs that is developed, documented in writing, and signed by the attending veterinarian. Correct by 
August 20, 2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.

Additional Inspectors: 
Michael Brooks, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER 
Ronald Richardson, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
